Hudson-Delange

Tomorrow afternoon Baltimore will
have its annual invasion by the Fords,
another way of saying that Homewood
will be the scene of the struggle between Johns Hopkins and Haverford,
which for the last few years has been
orie of the highlights of midseason
for both arrays.

Orchestra,

specialists in the new "subdued swing"
will be the featured attraction at the
First Cotillion, tentatively set for
Thursday, November 27th, it was an-

Regardless of the previous records
during the season of either of these
teams, these games here have been
hard, bruising contests and nearly
always dose and exciting. There is
every indication this year that the
contest will be every bit as hardfought as usual.

nounced last Wednesday by David
Erck, President of the Cotillion Board.
The occasion will mark the first appearance in Baltimore of a band which
is, according to Erck,"the premier exponent of the 'new' music."
In its announcement of the Hudson
booking, the Board also called attention to the second of a series of
Saturday Night Dances, to be held in
Levering Hall from nine to one tomorrow night.
Dance After Game
"We are calling Saturday's affair a
'Victory Dance,'„ said Erck, "in honor
of the Haverford game. The Townsmen have been signed for the dancers,
and no matter whose Victory will be
celebrated, both sides can expect a
good party."
The Hudson-Delange unit come._
Baltimore after a summer's engagement at Bampf, on Lake Louise, in
Canada. Early this fall it embarked
on a New England tour, which has
culminated in an engagement at the
Weirs, on Lake Winnepausaukee, New
Hampshire.
The personnel of the band is substantially the same as that which Eddie Delange was leading at the time
he began his partnership with Will
Hudson two years ago. Their subsequent use, say their followers, is unusual in that it has not gone in hand
With the engagement of "name" soloists.
Something Different
"Instead of featuring Roy Eldredges
and Choo Berrys," says one, "Gene
Krupas and Jesse Stacys, or Matty
Mattlocks and Ray Beauducs, Hudson
and Delange have sought to achieve
their effects by smartly-drilled, carefully integrated collective work. The
result shows in one of the most unusual bands now before the public."
Will Hudson, pianist and arranger,
is reputedly responsible for his band's
Style. Hudson, when he joined DeLange, was already known as the composer of songs like "Moonglow," "Remember When," and "Nitwit Serenade." He had done arrangements for
many of the nation's popular orchestras.
Since his rise as a leader, Hudson
has been chiefly occupied with the
carefully-scored rhythmitic exercises,
which are his orchestra's specialty. He
has produced "Hobo On Park Avenue,"
"Eight Bars in Search of A Melody,"
"Mr. Ghost Goes To Town," "CrossCountry Hap" and lately "Organ
Grinder's Swing." More in the "sweet"
Style are "Tormented" and "You're
Not The Kind."

Four Journals Issued
From Hopkins Press
Pour new journals have been recently issued in the Johns Hopkins
Pniversity Press. Two are comparative Psychology Monographs, numibers four and five of volume 13. Number four concerns itself with the Sensory Basis of Maze Learning in Rats,
authored by C. H. Hauzile of the
:University of California, while number five deals with Oestric, Receptivity, and Mating in Chimpanzees,
being compiled by Yerkes and Elder
of Yale.
, There is also a new number of the
Anierican Journal of Mathematics.
/ The journal on Modern Languages
Notes contains short articles on
Shakespeare, Dante, Shenstone, Hawthorne, and Chaucer.

No Injuries
Hopkins emerged from the Washington fray with no injuries. Their
—Courtesy News-Post near victory over the Shoremen arousED LOTZ
ed no end of confidence, and the
daily practises have been patterned
to stop the onslaughts of the visitors.
Thus far this season, the team from
Haverford has been soundly trounced
by a strong Williams machine from
Massachusetts in its opener, and last
week received the short end of a 12-6
Marburg Memorial score from Wesleyan.

Faculty Building
Nears Completion
New

Club Approaches
Completion
Slowly, but surely, though escaping
:he notice of the campus, the new
Theodore Marburg Memorial Faculty
Club is approaching completion, being
already well over halfway completed.
The new building has passed the point
at which it is possible to see how the
completed structure will look. The
faculty will most probably occupy the
club sometime after anuary first.
Since construction was started in
May, necessitating extensive diggingup of the campus, work has progressed
quite well. The roof, of slate, like
other University buildings, is complete.
The upper floors have been built, and
while still in a rough state are complete enough to bear the weight of further building supplies. Also ready and
being used is the circular stairway
which leads to the upper floor or the
basement from the lobby.
The work at present is mainly plastering, and installing tile, painting,
and in general preparing for the installation of electricity, for which already wires have been brought
through the woods ready to connect
When needed.
The club is Colonial in style and
brick and will resemble Levering Hall
when complete.

Associated Press
Dispatches

The Scarlet and Black are led by
Herb Tayler, who is playing his fourth
year as varsity fullback. Dick Beeler,
an inexperienced freshman, calls the
signals for the invaders at his quarterback position. Ambler and Holzer,
veterans at the art of blocking and
passing, round out the backfield at
the halfback stations. Up to this
point in the season, the effectiveness
of this quartet is unknown, but they
possess the fundamental knowledge of
their positions, a fact which will make
any secondary dangerous.
Ramsey Threatens
As for the line, •the important element in anyone's eleven, Ramsey
holds down the pivot position and
Childs will play one of the guard positions. Both of these men are seasoned and will form a good nucleus
for a young, green, line. Morian, veteran tackle of last year's eleven, has
been moved to end to bolster up the
flanks, weakened by graduation's de(Cont. on Page 3, Col. 1)

troduce Miss Thompson as "the bestknown and most feared of American
women, especially by European politicians."
Speaks On Presidency
Miss Thompson announced that she
would not speak on the subject which
had been suggested to her, but rather
upon the various reactions she had to
the present struggle for the presidency. "In three years of column-writing
I have spent my time reaaing and listening to the speeches and campaign
promises. I find that the things which
puzzle me are not the things which
are presented as campaign issues.
Matters of method and definition of
terms, which could be the only real
statements of difference between the
major parties, are left very much in
doubt. As an example, the entrance of
government into the economic life
of the country, either advocated or
derided by the orators, is at no place
given a true evaluation. The question is not so much whether, as how,
and under what conditions. We need
to know just what sort of administraion here will be, and what sort of men
will run the bureau or whatever legislative group is set up.
"All people seem divided into two
groups, those who see the ends only,
and those who see the means as well."
Those who look at the means of
arrival, are, so the speaker thinks,
the more reliable, since the end is

BY ARNOLD SERWER
Correspondent)
The Student Advocate, organ of the
American Student Union, is expected
to be an even more important influence on liberal student opinion this
year than it was last, in the opinion of
Joseph Lash, national executive secretary of the Union, whom I interviewed here.
One factor that will make this possible, according to Mr. Lash, is the recent endorsement of the next peace
strike by the YMCA and other church..
affiliated youth and student groups.
Last year •the American Student
Union and the Student Advocate bore
the entire burden of sponsoring and
planning a nationwide peace strike
against war that brought out a half
million student strikers. This one major activity absorbed most of the
Union's energies, leaving little time
for other parts of the Union's program. Now, with cooperating groups
sharing the burden of the organization
of the 1937 strike, the Union will be
free to drive for thousands of new
members, place additional emphasis
on its efforts on behalf of academic
freedom, and again fight Fascism on
the campus and strive for abolition of
the R. 0. T. C.

Musical Club To Hold
First Concert Dec. 4
The first musical club concert will
be held a St. Mark's Methodist Church
on December 4, it was announced today at the release of a tentative schedule. Recitals have also been arranged
for St. Paul's Choir Schools on December 12 and St. Mathews Lutheran
Church.
The highlight of the season for the
members of the musical, their trip
to Atlanic City, has been set for
March 13.

Boston, Mass. — (ACP) — Do you
want a second date with vivacious
Virginia, the gal you had out for the
first time the other night? Are you
going to get it ?---is the next question you want to ask yourself.

hasn't been discovered yet. Women of
Boston University have merely disclosed their particular peeves against
certain males with whom they
wouldn't care to date again, and it
sounds like a fairly reasonable list of
criticisms:
"Don't pun all the time.
Don't spend less than $.75 for a
'dinner.
Don't wear red neckties and don't
go without garters.
Don't kiss on the first date.
Don't eat onions, chew gum, or
drink when out on a date.
Don't ask a gal to spend any
money."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCTOBER 23, 1936

4

Fall Handball
Tourney Begins
On November 2

Lacrosse Managers
All freshmen candidates for lacrosse managerghips should report
to the gymnasium on Tuesday and
Friday afternoons at four o'clock.
It is necessary that all applicants
report now, rather than later in
the year, when the lacrosse season
is under way. This post affords
a good opportunity for a man to
be elected to the coveted lacrosse
managership, and any men at all
interested should try out.

Handball Box To Be Kept At
Gym With Complete
Equipment

Deadline Oct. 28
Informal Practices To Be
Held Once A
Week
On Monday, November 2, the third
annual Johns Hopkins handball tournament will begin at the gym.
The tournament will be run as

usual. Ladders will be placed at the
gym, each bearing ten names. Each
person on the ladder can challenge
anyone leas than three rungs above
him. At the end of four weeks, the
first four names on each ladder will
be entered in the playoffs. for the
championships.
Irving Milberg won the handball
championship last year. Richard Byer
took the silver medal while Tom Harrel and Nathaniel Finkelstein were the
semi-finalists.
Former Winners
All those who have won handball
medals are automatically disqualified from playing in the tournament.
This offers greater opportunities to
those who will enter the tournament
for the first time this year.
Captain Nathaniel Finkelstein foresees a very successful season. Former

Intramurals
Both the interclass and interfraternity football games ran off smoothly
last Tuesday as the Seven "J's" upset
last year's champions, the Soph Engineers, 6-0, and the Phi Sigma Delta
fraternity defeated Phi Alpha 12-0.
The Soph Engineers and Seven "J's"
played a closely contested game, the
only scare being made towards the
end. O'Neill was the main cog in the
Engineer's offensive machine. His
passing and running almost saved the
day. Reynolds and Ham were consistent receivers of his long passes,
but they never were able to cross the
coveted goal line. Seaman and Beeler
of the freshman "J's" were both outstanding. Sellman scored the only
goal of the game and Beeler, captain of the team, starred both offensively and defensively.
The Phi Sigma Delta fraternity
scored twice to beat the Phi Alpha
Septet in a fast and furious battle.
J. Gertman and Kenny Zierler, each
scored once for the Phi Sigs. M. Simen.9ky played a strong defensive game
for the Phi Sigs.
Although on the small end of the
score, the Phi Alpha team seemed to
outplay their opponents throughout
the game. A Lachman, L. Krakauer,
and I. Lefstein played consistently
good football.

Captain Joaquin Hernandez, Irving
Milberg, Richard Pasternak, Milton
Alperstein, and Red Glantz, experienced veterans from last year's teams

Rooters Hope To Dorms Annual Ping
Advance In League Pong Tournament
By Downing Terps Promises Thrills
Blue Jay Freshmen Beat
Forest Park High To
Tune Of 3-1
The Blue Jay Booters will attempt
to move ahead another notch in the
Maryland Collegiate soccer championship race when they meet the
University of Maryland Old Liners at
Homewood tomorrow. Eager and confident, after last week's trouncing of
Salisbury State Teachers, the team
expects to carry a fighting, driving
game to the Terrapins. Remembering last year's conquest of Maryland,
and with its new offense proven good,
the Booters are full of confidence.
The fros:i team, meanwhile, has
not been lax, but piled up a 3-1
victory over Forest Park High School
last Wednesday. Playing a very
speedy game, the boys managed to
get their three tallies, Freyer, Holman, and Briggs, booting the ball
for the score. Briggs, incidentally, is
part of the newly developed Blue Jay
Boc•ter offense, at center forward.

Sharpshooters Start
Practice November 15th
With the range opening on November 15th, the rifle Club swings into
action. The sharpshooters are one of
the oldest groups on the campus, having originated about 1920. Sergeant
Perry is faculty superviser. Rifle
team members are chosen from club
men. Dues are $2 the first year, and
$1 thereafter, entitling one to guns,
ammunition, and targets. With sixty men enrolled, membership Is expected to reach its usual total of
about seventy.

Ping-pong, a sport heretofore pracunknown on the Hopkins
tically
campus, is thriving in the Dormitory
and bids fair to become the most popular diversion among the students
there. The Third Annual Ping-pong
Tournament has offered more excitement and thrills in the present eliminations than has been seen previously
in the Dormitory competition.
While the field has yet to be narrowed, all favored contestants may
be seen constantly practicing in anticipation of bitterly contested battles
in the play-off round.
Len Rubinger, back after a period
of retirement looms as a current favorite. Rubinger battled his way to the
final round two years ago.. Lupo
Goldstein promises to reveal a new
stroke which he has been developing
in the depths of "A" entry. Vinny
Giacinto, runner-up in the'35 eliminations must be considered a definite
threat to any prospective champ.

INTERCOLLEGIATE
FOOTBALL—Johns Hopkins vs.
Haverford, Saturday, at Homewood.
SOCCER—Johns Hopkins vs. University of Maryland, Saturday,
at Homewood.
CROSS - COUNTRY — Johns Hopkins vs. Lehigh University, Saturday, at Homewood.

Fall Lacrosse
The candidates at the fall lacrosse
practice received their taste of box
lacrosse Tuesday when Coach Kelso
Morrill put them in the "cage" for the
first time.
The scrimmage lasted only thirty
minutes, but it was long enough for
such varsity performers as Naylor,
Himes, Ghinger, Melvin, and Seigal
to show inklings of their stickwork.

Practice To Start
Intending to get an early start this
year, the Hopkins basketball team
will begin official practice under
Coach Utz Twardowitz on Wednesday at 4 P.M. Coaches Twardowitz
and Gardner M.allonke direct the
courtrnen together. Coach Mallonee
will not be out until the football season is over.

Hudson-Delange

Tomorrow afternoon Baltimore will
have its annual invasion by the Fords,
another way of saying that Homewood
will be the scene of the struggle between Johns Hopkins and Haverford,
which for the last few years has been
orie of the highlights of midseason
for both arrays.

Orchestra,

specialists in the new "subdued swing"
will be the featured attraction at the
First Cotillion, tentatively set for
Thursday, November 27th, it was an-

Regardless of the previous records
during the season of either of these
teams, these games here have been
hard, bruising contests and nearly
always dose and exciting. There is
every indication this year that the
contest will be every bit as hardfought as usual.

nounced last Wednesday by David
Erck, President of the Cotillion Board.
The occasion will mark the first appearance in Baltimore of a band which
is, according to Erck,"the premier exponent of the 'new' music."
In its announcement of the Hudson
booking, the Board also called attention to the second of a series of
Saturday Night Dances, to be held in
Levering Hall from nine to one tomorrow night.
Dance After Game
"We are calling Saturday's affair a
'Victory Dance,'„ said Erck, "in honor
of the Haverford game. The Townsmen have been signed for the dancers,
and no matter whose Victory will be
celebrated, both sides can expect a
good party."
The Hudson-Delange unit come._
Baltimore after a summer's engagement at Bampf, on Lake Louise, in
Canada. Early this fall it embarked
on a New England tour, which has
culminated in an engagement at the
Weirs, on Lake Winnepausaukee, New
Hampshire.
The personnel of the band is substantially the same as that which Eddie Delange was leading at the time
he began his partnership with Will
Hudson two years ago. Their subsequent use, say their followers, is unusual in that it has not gone in hand
With the engagement of "name" soloists.
Something Different
"Instead of featuring Roy Eldredges
and Choo Berrys," says one, "Gene
Krupas and Jesse Stacys, or Matty
Mattlocks and Ray Beauducs, Hudson
and Delange have sought to achieve
their effects by smartly-drilled, carefully integrated collective work. The
result shows in one of the most unusual bands now before the public."
Will Hudson, pianist and arranger,
is reputedly responsible for his band's
Style. Hudson, when he joined DeLange, was already known as the composer of songs like "Moonglow," "Remember When," and "Nitwit Serenade." He had done arrangements for
many of the nation's popular orchestras.
Since his rise as a leader, Hudson
has been chiefly occupied with the
carefully-scored rhythmitic exercises,
which are his orchestra's specialty. He
has produced "Hobo On Park Avenue,"
"Eight Bars in Search of A Melody,"
"Mr. Ghost Goes To Town," "CrossCountry Hap" and lately "Organ
Grinder's Swing." More in the "sweet"
Style are "Tormented" and "You're
Not The Kind."

authored by C. H. Hauzile of the
:University of California, while number five deals with Oestric, Receptivity, and Mating in Chimpanzees,
being compiled by Yerkes and Elder
of Yale.
, There is also a new number of the
Anierican Journal of Mathematics.
/ The journal on Modern Languages
Notes contains short articles on
Shakespeare, Dante, Shenstone, Hawthorne, and Chaucer.

Faculty Building
Nears Completion
New

Club Approaches
Completion
Slowly, but surely, though escaping
:he notice of the campus, the new
Theodore Marburg Memorial Faculty
Club is approaching completion, being
already well over halfway completed.
The new building has passed the point
at which it is possible to see how the
completed structure will look. The
faculty will most probably occupy the
club sometime after anuary first.
Since construction was started in
May, necessitating extensive diggingup of the campus, work has progressed
quite well. The roof, of slate, like
other University buildings, is complete.
The upper floors have been built, and
while still in a rough state are complete enough to bear the weight of further building supplies. Also ready and
being used is the circular stairway
which leads to the upper floor or the
basement from the lobby.
The work at present is mainly plastering, and installing tile, painting,
and in general preparing for the installation of electricity, for which already wires have been brought
through the woods ready to connect
When needed.
The club is Colonial in style and
brick and will resemble Levering Hall
when complete.

BY ARNOLD SERWER
Correspondent)
The Student Advocate, organ of the
American Student Union, is expected
to be an even more important influence on liberal student opinion this
year than it was last, in the opinion of
Joseph Lash, national executive secretary of the Union, whom I interviewed here.
One factor that will make this possible, according to Mr. Lash, is the recent endorsement of the next peace
strike by the YMCA and other church..
affiliated youth and student groups.
Last year •the American Student
Union and the Student Advocate bore
the entire burden of sponsoring and
planning a nationwide peace strike
against war that brought out a half
million student strikers. This one major activity absorbed most of the
Union's energies, leaving little time
for other parts of the Union's program. Now, with cooperating groups
sharing the burden of the organization
of the 1937 strike, the Union will be
free to drive for thousands of new
members, place additional emphasis
on its efforts on behalf of academic
freedom, and again fight Fascism on
the campus and strive for abolition of
the R. 0. T. C.

The following paragraph appeared
In the NEWS-LETTER May 20:

sion. He changed his mind, a lucky
decision for millions of American men
and women. Robert Taft, a member of
Governor Landon's "staff of advisers,"
has endorsed Roosevelt's fiscal policies, protesting against "billing the
constituted representatives of the people."
The "Alphabet Soup" of the present administration is preferable from
a moral standpoint to the dole. I cannot argue with anyone about that.
Landon praises the C.C.C. I think the
N.Y.A. is a noble idea. Students earn
the forty cents an hour, at least, this
one does.
Dean Acheson and James Warbury,
intelligent men of public affairs, despite former criticism of the president,
cannot stomach the G.O.P. nominee's
narrow economic policies, which are
daily growing more ridiculous as Cordell Hull's policy of economic liberalism is gaining acceptance throughout Europe. Witness the recent actions
of France, of the Netherlands, and of
Switzerland. Attention, William Randolph Hearst!
Should Landon be elected, I predict
tha within six months high tariffs will
again prevail and ships will lie accumulating barnacles in harbor, only
to be remade into fast, camoflauged
vessels of war, to destroy and ravage
the places to which they had formerly
carried welcome cargoes. I am positive that the American people will not
even create the conditions that will allow this to come to pass.
Just

Boston, Mass. — (ACP) — Do you
want a second date with vivacious
Virginia, the gal you had out for the
first time the other night? Are you
going to get it ?---is the next question you want to ask yourself.

Boston University have merely disclosed their particular peeves against

wouldn't care to date again, and it
sounds like a fairly reasonable list of
criticisms:
"Don't pun all the time.
Don't spend less than $.75 for a
'dinner.
Don't wear red neckties and don't
go without garters.
Don't kiss on the first date.
Don't eat onions, chew gum, or
drink when out on a date.
Don't ask a gal to spend any
money."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCTOBER 23, 1936

4

Fall Handball
Tourney Begins
On November 2

Lacrosse Managers
All freshmen candidates for lacrosse managerghips should report
to the gymnasium on Tuesday and
Friday afternoons at four o'clock.
It is necessary that all applicants
report now, rather than later in
the year, when the lacrosse season
is under way. This post affords
a good opportunity for a man to
be elected to the coveted lacrosse
managership, and any men at all
interested should try out.

Handball Box To Be Kept At
Gym With Complete
Equipment

Deadline Oct. 28
Informal Practices To Be
Held Once A
Week
On Monday, November 2, the third
annual Johns Hopkins handball tournament will begin at the gym.
The tournament will be run as

usual. Ladders will be placed at the
gym, each bearing ten names. Each
person on the ladder can challenge
anyone leas than three rungs above
him. At the end of four weeks, the
first four names on each ladder will
be entered in the playoffs. for the
championships.
Irving Milberg won the handball
championship last year. Richard Byer
took the silver medal while Tom Harrel and Nathaniel Finkelstein were the
semi-finalists.
Former Winners
All those who have won handball
medals are automatically disqualified from playing in the tournament.
This offers greater opportunities to
those who will enter the tournament
for the first time this year.
Captain Nathaniel Finkelstein foresees a very successful season. Former

Intramurals
Both the interclass and interfraternity football games ran off smoothly
last Tuesday as the Seven "J's" upset
last year's champions, the Soph Engineers, 6-0, and the Phi Sigma Delta
fraternity defeated Phi Alpha 12-0.
The Soph Engineers and Seven "J's"
played a closely contested game, the
only scare being made towards the
end. O'Neill was the main cog in the
Engineer's offensive machine. His
passing and running almost saved the
day. Reynolds and Ham were consistent receivers of his long passes,
but they never were able to cross the
coveted goal line. Seaman and Beeler
of the freshman "J's" were both outstanding. Sellman scored the only
goal of the game and Beeler, captain of the team, starred both offensively and defensively.
The Phi Sigma Delta fraternity
scored twice to beat the Phi Alpha
Septet in a fast and furious battle.
J. Gertman and Kenny Zierler, each
scored once for the Phi Sigs. M. Simen.9ky played a strong defensive game
for the Phi Sigs.
Although on the small end of the
score, the Phi Alpha team seemed to
outplay their opponents throughout
the game. A Lachman, L. Krakauer,
and I. Lefstein played consistently
good football.

Captain Joaquin Hernandez, Irving
Milberg, Richard Pasternak, Milton
Alperstein, and Red Glantz, experienced veterans from last year's teams

Rooters Hope To Dorms Annual Ping
Advance In League Pong Tournament
By Downing Terps Promises Thrills
Blue Jay Freshmen Beat
Forest Park High To
Tune Of 3-1
The Blue Jay Booters will attempt
to move ahead another notch in the
Maryland Collegiate soccer championship race when they meet the
University of Maryland Old Liners at
Homewood tomorrow. Eager and confident, after last week's trouncing of
Salisbury State Teachers, the team
expects to carry a fighting, driving
game to the Terrapins. Remembering last year's conquest of Maryland,
and with its new offense proven good,
the Booters are full of confidence.
The fros:i team, meanwhile, has
not been lax, but piled up a 3-1
victory over Forest Park High School
last Wednesday. Playing a very
speedy game, the boys managed to
get their three tallies, Freyer, Holman, and Briggs, booting the ball
for the score. Briggs, incidentally, is
part of the newly developed Blue Jay
Boc•ter offense, at center forward.

Sharpshooters Start
Practice November 15th
With the range opening on November 15th, the rifle Club swings into
action. The sharpshooters are one of
the oldest groups on the campus, having originated about 1920. Sergeant
Perry is faculty superviser. Rifle
team members are chosen from club
men. Dues are $2 the first year, and
$1 thereafter, entitling one to guns,
ammunition, and targets. With sixty men enrolled, membership Is expected to reach its usual total of
about seventy.

Ping-pong, a sport heretofore pracunknown on the Hopkins
tically
campus, is thriving in the Dormitory
and bids fair to become the most popular diversion among the students
there. The Third Annual Ping-pong
Tournament has offered more excitement and thrills in the present eliminations than has been seen previously
in the Dormitory competition.
While the field has yet to be narrowed, all favored contestants may
be seen constantly practicing in anticipation of bitterly contested battles
in the play-off round.
Len Rubinger, back after a period
of retirement looms as a current favorite. Rubinger battled his way to the
final round two years ago.. Lupo
Goldstein promises to reveal a new
stroke which he has been developing
in the depths of "A" entry. Vinny
Giacinto, runner-up in the'35 eliminations must be considered a definite
threat to any prospective champ.

Sport Schedule
INTERCOLLEGIATE
FOOTBALL—Johns Hopkins vs.
Haverford, Saturday, at Homewood.
SOCCER—Johns Hopkins vs. University of Maryland, Saturday,
at Homewood.
CROSS - COUNTRY — Johns Hopkins vs. Lehigh University, Saturday, at Homewood.

Fall Lacrosse
The candidates at the fall lacrosse
practice received their taste of box
lacrosse Tuesday when Coach Kelso
Morrill put them in the "cage" for the
first time.
The scrimmage lasted only thirty
minutes, but it was long enough for
such varsity performers as Naylor,
Himes, Ghinger, Melvin, and Seigal
to show inklings of their stickwork.

Practice To Start
Intending to get an early start this
year, the Hopkins basketball team
will begin official practice under
Coach Utz Twardowitz on Wednesday at 4 P.M. Coaches Twardowitz
and Gardner M.allonke direct the
courtrnen together. Coach Mallonee
will not be out until the football season is over.
